awd_titl_txt: Conference: Building Teams to Build Better Epidemiological Models: Balancing Participation from Mathematical and Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support two separate one-day virtual conferences entitled “Building Teams to Build Better Epidemiological Models: Balancing Participation from Mathematical and Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences” (https://sites.duke.edu/betterepidemiologicalmodelsconference/), to be held in January 2025. In a crisis such as the COVID-19 pandemic, mathematical models played their role in designing, developing, deploying, and evaluating public health strategies with different levels of success. Still, all were confronted with prioritizing public health or economic viability. To frame a sound pandemic response strategy, mathematical models are primary tools that must incorporate behavioral components and frameworks to be more efficient and useful for public health policy interventions and the evaluation of the economic impact of such measures. The COVID-19 pandemic highlights the need to develop mathematical methodologies, new techniques, and innovative approaches designed to incorporate the new paradigm of behavioral dynamics into the transmission dynamics of human diseases. Multidisciplinary teams are needed to innovate new mathematical methodologies which incorporate human behavioral and social dynamics. This award will be used to support a conference to bring together mathematical and social / behavioral / economic scientists to develop improved epidemiological models which can protect both public health and the economy. Applicants will be selected to balance these research areas, with attention given during the selection process to ensure that women and members of underrepresented groups are fully considered with an eye to broadening participation.

The standard framework for the mathematical modeling of infectious diseases is the basic Kermack-McKendrick model, a compartmental model framed in ordinary differential equations and their extensions to stochastic and hybrid models. Mixing is a random process in this framework, and this characteristic has pervaded in models for prediction and forecasting and is one, but not unique, of the most challenging and important topics in modeling infectious diseases: how to modify the basic assumption of the homogeneous population in the model to incorporate significant behavioral effects robustly and effectively. For example, there have been several efforts in literature to integrate behavior; one of them is the one that assumes that agents that interact during the transmission of the disease are rational, i.e., the individuals behave in a way consistent with a rational evaluation of risks. This model type is based on economic thinking in which costs and benefits are balanced, where there is a trade-off that rational agents resolve. The problem in epidemiology is that many of the actions of natural agents during an epidemic do not adapt to this hypothesis; therefore, applying this type of modeling requires the development of innovative ideas, alternative conceptual frameworks, and new mathematical techniques and methodologies. Scientific teams which can innovate and parameterize mathematical models which are tractable, represent an analogue of human behavior and transmission, work across a variety of domains and settings, and can be used to test interventions are needed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The recent COVID-19 pandemic has underscored a critical shortcoming in today's mathematical models – they often do not incorporate human behavior, a complex and multifaceted factor influenced by individual, socioeconomic, and cultural elements. Integrating behavioral aspects into classical mathematical models is still in its early stages, and existing attempts have proven insufficient for informing the design of public health policies and implementing successful intervention, control, and mitigation strategies. 

 

The NSF Division of Mathematical Sciences has been actively promoting and funding research projects that address the need to improve the descriptive, explanatory, and predictive capabilities of mathematical models directed to the theoretical and practical understanding of the population dynamics of infectious diseases and other related phenomena. One basic factor that the NSF committees identified is the need for multidisciplinary transdisciplinary methodologies and work if the complex interactions between disease transmission and human social and psychological components are to be effectively integrated into the modeling framework.  The program that NSF implemented to address this need is Integrating Human Behavior to Mathematical Models which was one of its five highlights of the period 2020 to 2023.  Based on this background, a workshop entitled Building Teams to Build Better Epidemiological Models was designed and funded to support NSF’s initiative to develop new, innovative, and multidisciplinary approaches and modeling methods for the mathematical treatment of epidemics. 

 

Applications were solicited from scientists and researchers who are eligible for NSF funding beginning on 18-November-2024 and the application period closed on 08-December-2024.  During this three-week period, 90 applications were received and ultimately 80 were selected for attendance.  Two virtual conference days were convened on January 14 and 17, 2025 with the goal of bringing together mathematical and social/behavioral/economic (SBE) scientists to form teams to develop innovative models to predict and prevent pandemics.  Across both conference days, 73 scientists participated (33 on 14-January and 40 on 17-January).  There was no fee to register for or attend the conference.  Most attendees were current faculty, with a balance of Assistant Professors (45%) and post-tenure rank faculty (43%).  Nearly half of attendees (45%) had previously received NSF funding as PI or senior personnel.  Just over one-third (36%) had previously applied to NSF for funding but were not successful.

 

The workshop was organized by assigning participants into groups. The balance of perspectives between mathematical and social / behavioral / economic sciences was achieved in the following manner. In the morning session, the organizers assembled the teams, assigning participants to groups to identify significant topics and research areas related to the problem. Team members were allowed to move freely between the different groups to achieve a more critical and robust conceptual view of the situation and to increase the diversity of opinions and views. In this first session, participant group numbers ranged from three to 11. After the morning session, a set of breakout rooms was established, to which participants could subscribe.  The organizers were careful to maintain a balance between mathematical and SBE scientists, the bottom line being that at least one researcher was identified as an SBE scientist. At the end of the workshop, all breakout groups, through a representative, expressed their opinions, views, and lessons learned from the interaction. This served to the organizers as a way of detecting if the aims of the workshop were correctly addressed and the goal achieved.

 

The main challenge of organizing and implementing the workshop was to strike a balance between mathematical and SBE scientists, not in terms of numbers, but in perspective. With three times as many mathematical scientists as SBE scientists participating in the conference, the dominance of the mathematical disciplinary perspective was significant.  This was reflected in the responses of a survey sent immediately after the conference ended (n=34 responses).  SBE and early-career scientists had a more positive view of the conference.  All follow-up survey respondents indicated that they either planned to continue working with other conference attendees or were unsure about their future plans; none of the respondents stated that they had no future plans to work with conference attendees.  Unsurprisingly, overall perceptions of the conference correlated with solid plans to continue working with connections made at the conference, which may account for the higher degree of satisfaction among the SBE scientists as the imbalance provided more opportunities for them to form connections.  From a later follow-up survey with 19 respondents, 4 primarily SBE scientists (2 full and 2 assistant professors) and 4 primarily mathematical scientists (1 full, 1 associate, and 2 assistant professors) who attended the conference were part of 2025 IHBEM submissions with colleagues whom they met during the conference.  The workshop highlighted a strong desire for mathematical scientists to find SBE scientist partners, which identifies an NSF opportunity area to be developed to enhance the multidisciplinary thinking and methodology required to address complex epidemiological systems.
